I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries1 are in the process of building capacity 
of their national institutions responsible for integrating the environmental issues in the power 
system  planning  and  ensuring  sustainable  development  of  power  sectors.  The  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  already  supporting  regional  energy  cooperation  in  the  GMS 
through the 2007 regional technical assistance (TA) project Facilitating Regional Power Trading 
and  Environmentally  Sustainable  Development  of  Electricity  Infrastructure  in  the  Greater 
Mekong  Subregion. 2  The  2007  TA,  among  other  outputs,  formulated  the  GMS  Power 
Transmission  Master  Plan  (the  GMS  master  plan),  which  proposes  building  new  power 
generation and transmission infrastructure facilities to satisfy the growing demand for energy in 
the GMS from 2010 to 2025. However, the master plan, which employs a traditional least-cost 
approach, needs to incorporate environmental and social impact assessments of the planned 
infrastructure facilities. Further there is a pressing need to build the capacity of key GMS 
agencies and utilities to manage and mitigate the social and environmental impacts of these 
facilities. In this regard, the governments of the GMS countries requested TA from ADB to 
undertake a strategic environmental assessment (SEA) of the GMS master plan.3 The TA 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  GMS economies grew at an annual rate of about 7% between 2000 and 2009, and this 
trend is forecasted to continue in the medium and long term. As a result of this rapid economic 
expansion, demand for energy in the GMS is projected to increase on average by 7% per year 
during 2009–2025, even taking into consideration energy efficiency improvement and demand 
side management. Electricity generation from natural gas is forecasted to double during 2005–
2025, while the use of coal will increase fourfold. As the GMS increasingly depends on fossil 
fuels, the amount of greenhouse gas and other pollution entering the atmosphere is rising 
rapidly. It is estimated that the environmental cost of GMS energy consumption will total $320 
billion during 2005–2025.4 
 
3.  SEA is a structured process of integrating social and environmental considerations into 
strategic decision making, such as the formulation of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan. 
The GMS has a decade-long history of energy cooperation, but the SEA of energy development 
is relatively new so it was not originally incorporated in the GMS Master Plan. The TA will 
prepare a SEA of the GMS master plan. By recommending incorporation of environmental and 
social considerations in the GMS Master Plan before its implementation, the SEA will essentially 
ensure its sustainability. 
 
4.  The master plan uses a traditional least-cost approach that takes into account only the 
financial costs of electricity generation and transmission. It neglects to fully account for local 
environmental and social costs (e.g., local pollution and impacts on public health, and livelihood 
disruptions),  global  environmental  costs  (greenhouse  gas  emissions  and  global  warming),

opportunity  costs  of  indigenous  resources,  scarcity  rent 5 of  fossil  fuels,  and  increased 
vulnerability of GMS countries to high and/or volatile energy prices. The TA will formulate 
alternative  scenarios  to  the  master  plan's  current  ("baseline")  scenario.  The  alternative 
scenarios  will  incorporate  ambitious  uses  of  renewable  energy,  and  other  environmentally 
progressive measures. The alternative scenarios will also incorporate more aggressive demand 
side management and mitigate risks associated with fuel price volatility and the depletion of 
indigenous fossil energy resources. 
 
5.  One critical impediment to ensuring sustainable energy is the limited capacity of the 
national  agencies  responsible  for  integrating  environmental  issues  into  energy  planning. 
Although capacity varies from country to country, capacity gaps exist at the national level within 
all  six  GMS  countries.  The  countries  with  the  most  hydropower  potential  (Cambodia,  Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic, and Myanmar), which are expected to account for the majority of 
power projects in the GMS through 2025, have the greatest need for improved institutional 
capacity. The SEA of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan will provide a comprehensive 
case for undertaking capacity development in these countries. It will recommend strengthening 
knowledge-sharing  and  experience-exchange  programs,  and  will  encourage  less-developed 
countries to learn from more-developed ones. 
 
6.  The TA will support the advancement of two strategic thrusts of the GMS regional 
cooperation  strategy: 6 (i)  strengthening  connectivity  and  facilitating  cross-border  trade, 
investment, and tourism; and (ii) managing the environment and shared natural resources to 
help ensure sustainable development and conservation of natural resources. The TA activities 
will capitalize upon ADB's cooperation with the Mekong River Commission (MRC), particularly 
MRC's ongoing work on the cumulative impact assessment of eleven proposed hydro-dams on 
the  Lower  Mekong  under  MRC  Initiative  on  Sustainable  Hydropower. 7  The  TA  also 
complements  the  MRC's  Environmental  Program  and  the  MRC's  Climate  Change  and 
Adaptation Initiative. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact of the proposed TA will be a more environmentally and socially sustainable 
regional electricity supply system in GMS countries. 
 
8.  The  expected  outcome  will  be  enhanced  capacity  of  GMS  country  energy  and 
environmental planning agencies and utilities to undertake SEA in energy planning. As a result 
of the TA, these entities will be prepared to manage the energy sector in a more sustainable and 
environmentally friendly manner, taking into account environmental and social externalities, fuel 
price volatility risks, energy security, energy dependency, and opportunity costs.

today equals to the sum of the marginal extraction cost for the fuel and scarcity rent.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA will employ a  team of consultants to develop an SEA of the GMS Power 
Transmission Master Plan and formulate three alternative scenarios to the master plan baseline 
scenario, involving as much as possible GMS agencies in this work.  
 
10.  The TA will deliver three main outputs: (i) an SEA of the GMS Power Transmission 
Master Plan; (ii) two alternative scenarios to the master plan, including detailed assessments of 
the environmental and social impacts of each scenario; and (iii) strengthened capacity of GMS 
government agencies and utilities to develop SEAs. 
 
11.  The key activity for the first output is to develop a complete SEA of the master plan 
baseline scenario. The SEA should include a detailed analysis of the master plan's planned 
power generation resources (coal, gas, oil, and hydro), and should also assess its renewable 
energy  components  (wind,  solar,  and  bio-mass),  energy  efficiency  components,  and  other 
environmental elements. The SEA should analyze the social and environmental impacts of each 
proposed investment outlined in the master plan. It should also assess clean-energy measures 
currently  being  undertaken  by  national  utilities  and  government  agencies,  and  should  be 
consistent with national power development plans.8 Based on weighting and trade-off analysis9 
and sensitivity analysis, the SEA will be used as a basis to formulate policy recommendations 
(including environmental and climate change mitigation and adaptation measures) to make the 
regional master plan more environmentally friendly and socially sustainable.  
 
12.  The key activities for second output of the TA are: 
(i)  Formulate renewable energy intensive alternative scenario to the GMS Power 
Transmission Master Plan. The renewable energy alternative scenario should 
incorporate  more  ambitious  renewable  energy  targets  (both  hydro  and  non-
hydro), taking into account the economic potential of renewable energy for each 
country.  Estimations  of  economic  potential  should  consider  the  geographic 
location of the renewable energy resource, the national grid and its planned 
development during the planning horizon 2025, and the technical limitations of 
grid  interconnection  for  highly  intermittent  renewable  energy  resources.  The 
master plan and national power development plans will be used as the main data 
sources  for  the  estimation  of  economic  potential  for  each  renewable  energy 
resource.  
(ii)  Develop an alternative energy security scenario will be elaborated, considering 
more aggressive demand side management, energy efficiency, and conservation 
options for the GMS countries. Studies carried out by the World Bank, ADB, and 
other development partners in the GMS (particularly in the People’s Republic of 
China, Thailand, and Viet Nam) will be considered, as will reports on sectoral 
saving potential carried out by government agencies and utilities in each country. 
Ongoing projects supported by ADB, including efficient power generation based 
on biomass and biowaste, will be considered. 
(iii)  Apply SEA to all alternative scenarios to the GMS master plan. The SEAs will 
evaluate the environmental and social externalities of power plants (fossil fuel-
based and hydropower projects) proposed in the alternative scenarios, and will

13.  The key activities for the third output are as follows: 
(i)  Prepare guidelines for undertaking SEA, with a case study being output 1. The 
guidelines  will  clearly  outline  the  steps,  milestones,  and  corresponding 
intermediate outputs of each step in the SEA process. 
(ii)  Assess the existing capacities of GMS member countries, e.g., environmental 
and  energy  ministries  and  utilities,  in  applying  SEAs  into  national  power 
development plans. Identify knowledge gaps for each country, and propose a 
matrix of actions for further capacity building TA. 
(iii)  Develop a training program, which includes workshops covering key steps and 
milestones of the SEA, analysis of key results from SEAs, and formulating policy 
recommendations based on SEAs.   
 
14.  On the basis of the capacity building for SEA on regional level as outlined above, an in-
depth capacity building program will be undertaken to address specific gaps and needs at 
national level in GMS countries. The capacity building needs identified under this TA will be 
addressed, and capacity building will be undertaken in a follow-up TA to be developed in 
consultation with GMS countries and potential development partners. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $1.35 million equivalent. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Government of France through Agence Francaise de Developpement and 
administered by ADB.11 The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA and will provide administration and support 
services. The Southeast Asia Department will oversee the TA. The focal point for participating 
countries will be the ministry or agency responsible for preparing the power sector development 
plan. Each country will nominate its focal point prior to the commencement of the TA. Focal 
points will participate in the meetings of the Regional Power Trade Coordination Committee in 
GMS.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented by an international consulting firm, which will provide 55 
person–months (27 months international and 28 months national consultants). The TA will 
commence in March 2011 and will be completed in September 2012. The terms of reference for

18.  The  TA  consultants  will  work  with  national  focal  points  to  establish  project 
implementation  teams  from  counterpart  agencies,  and  will  hire  the  counterpart  staff  to  be 
engaged in the TA implementation. The consultant will submit inception, interim, draft final, and 
final reports. The team leader of the consulting firm will be responsible for submitting the 
reports. The outputs will be disseminated by a variety of means, including website publication, 
in-country workshops, and electronic reports.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,350,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Government of France through Agence Francaise de Developpement, for 
Ensuring  Sustainability  of  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  Regional  Power  Development,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objectives and Scope of Work 
 
1.  The  implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  the  services  of  a 
multidisciplinary  team  of  consultants  comprising  international  and  national  consultants.  An 
international firm of consultants will be engaged for this assignment. This firm will be expected 
to procure the services of both international and national experts to undertake the components 
of the assignment. The firm will be responsible for the quality and timely delivery of the entire 
assignment. It is important that the international consultant firm procure the services of national 
experts with deep knowledge of the national energy sector and environmental issues and 
policies. National experts can represent a national firm or can be individual consultants. 
 
2.  The objective of the TA is to assist the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries in 
developing a reliable and environmentally and socially sustainable regional electricity supply 
system in the GMS. 
 
3.  The scope of work is to complete the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan (2010–
2025) by undertaking a strategic environmental assessment (SEA) of the plan. The TA will:  
(i)  take over the process of elaboration of the GMS Power Transmission Master 
Plan  and  take  into  account  environmental  and  social  impacts  of  projects 
proposed; 
(ii)  adjust baseline situations in each country to have a consistent modeling of the 
regional  power  sector,  which  will  allow  to  propose  alternative  demand  and 
production scenarios, based on more aggressive hypothesis on demand side 
management, development of renewable energies and consideration of energy 
security issues; and 
(iii)  propose  a  capacity  building  program  for  key  GMS  agencies  and  utilities  to 
address environmental, climate change, social externalities, energy security and 
energy efficiency measures in future power planning and policies formulation. 
 
4.  The consulting team will provide expertise for undertaking an SEA of the GMS Power 
Transmission Master Plan. The consulting team will be responsible for: 
(i)  assessing the current situation related to the environment,  and energy and 
power  sector  (including  energy  security)  in GMS  countries, including  climate 
change mitigation activities, national energy policies, and power sector legal and 
regulatory frameworks; 
(ii)  formulating  alternative  scenarios  to  the  master  plan's  baseline  scenario 
considering  optimization  of  investments  and  taking  into  account  valuation  of 
environmental and social externalities of the different power plants (fossil fuel-
based and hydropower projects) and transmission projects. For this task the 
results of the ongoing Mekong River Commission (MRC) initiatives and other 
regional studies should be incorporated. Alternative scenarios to be developed 
are: 
  
(a)  renewable energy scenario, which incorporates more ambitious 
renewable  energy  targets  and  strategies  (with  reference  to 
renewable energy policies and taking into account the economic 
potential of renewable energy resources for each country);  
(b)  energy  security  scenario,  which  incorporates  more  aggressive 
demand-side  management,  energy  efficiency  and  conservation

(i)  baseline assessment of the current situation related to the environment, socio-
economic, and climate change mitigation policies and activities at national level 
and  a  regional  synopsis  including  geographical  information  system  (GIS)

B.   International Consultants (27 person-months) 
 
6.  Strategic environmental assessment specialist and team leader (international, 5 
person-months). The team leader will guide and manage the work and coordinate the work plan 
with national focal points and agencies. The SEA specialist will guide and coordinate national 
and international experts in producing the SEA of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan; 
coordinate the team's work on the master plan SEA with ongoing MRC initiatives and other 
regional studies; present the SEAs at workshops and report on lessons learned; and prepare a 
summary of comments and feedback on the SEA of the master plan. The specialist will take the 
lead in designing and implementing a training program on SEA and energy security planning. 
The team leader will be responsible for submission of the TA deliverables and reports. The team 
leader should possess excellent management skills and relevant experience in SEA, planning, 
and  policy,  and  should  have  at  least  12  years  of  experience  in  environmental  impact 
assessment theories and practices. Experience in producing SEAs of power development plans 
and projects in the GMS region is an advantage. The expert should have skills in training and 
capacity building. 
 
7.  Energy  specialist  and  deputy  team  leader  (international,  4  person-months).  The 
deputy team leader will assist the team leader with project management. The deputy team 
leader will coordinate the activities of the international experts in renewable energy, energy 
efficiency, hydropower, and energy economics, and will oversee the national energy experts' 
work on assessment of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan baseline scenario, and 
prepare a regional summary of energy trends. The deputy team leader will take the lead in 
formulating the three alternative scenarios to the master plan baseline scenario, and will lead 
the analyses of these scenarios to be included in the SEAs, together with the power system 
analyst and other international experts. The deputy team leader will be responsible for compiling 
the TA deliverables and reports, and will assist the team leader in presenting the SEAs at 
training workshops and programs. The deputy team leader should have a background in energy 
planning, policy, and economics, and should have at least 12 years experience in energy 
planning and environment safeguards. Experience in implementing energy planning in the GMS 
region is an advantage. The specialist should have skills in training and capacity building. 
 
8.  Environment and climate change specialist (international, 3 person-months). The 
specialist will take the lead in formulating and collecting environmental and climate change data 
for the SEA of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan, covering fossil fuel-based and hydro-
based power generation for each GMS country. The specialist will take the lead in monetizing 
environmental and climate change impacts, with special attention to studies carried out by other 
development  partners  in  GMS  countries.  He  or  she  will  take  the  lead  in  identifying 
environmental benefits originating from regional GMS power system integration and the master 
plan. The specialist will propose climate change mitigation and adaptation measures, and will 
identify opportunities to implement these measures, taking into account differing national goals. 
The specialist will make policy recommendations related to the mitigation and adaptation of 
adverse environmental and climate change impacts. The specialist should have at least 10 
years of experience in environmental impact assessment and energy planning. He or she 
should have strong experience in environmental externality valuation, environmental economics 
and policy, and international best practices. Knowledge of renewable energy planning and 
financing, including experience with market mechanisms for greenhouse gas mitigation (such as 
Clean Development Mechanism and carbon financing) is an advantage. Experience in the GMS 
region is an advantage.

12  Appendix 3      
9.  Power system analyst (international, 2.5 person-months). The power system analyst 
will manage the transfer of the database and optimization software from the 2007 regional TA 
(footnote 1) to the new TA. The analyst will lead the modeling work in formulating alternative 
scenarios to the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan, and will identify the potentially most 
beneficial regional generation and interconnection projects. If found necessary, the analyst will 
propose an alternative list of priority projects in the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan for 
2010–2025. He or she will take the lead in designing and implementing the training program on 
energy planning, and the operation of the power optimization model. The power system analyst 
should have sound knowledge of energy planning and should have skills in power system 
expansion, optimization, and simulation of alternative scenarios. The analyst should have at 
least 8 years of experience and should be skilled in training and capacity building. 
 
10.  Energy  economist  (international,  2.5  person-months).  The  energy  economist  will 
assess the methodology of cost–benefit assessment of power trading developed under the 2007 
regional  TA,  and  will  introduce  modifications  to  capture  environmental,  social,  and  energy 
security benefits. The economist will take the lead in analyzing the risks associated with fuel 
price volatility, supply disruptions, and financial crises, as well as the depletion of indigenous 
exhaustible  resources  (including  sensitivity  analysis  related  to  electricity  demand  and  fuel 
prices).  The  economist  will  lead  the  analysis  of  the  economic  benefits  of  the  alternative 
scenarios to the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan (including sensitivity analysis). He or 
she will provide policy recommendations based on cost–benefit assessment of regional energy 
trade and mitigation of external risks. The specialist will lead the design and implementation of 
the training program on portfolio-based planning. The energy economist should have at least 10 
years of experience in energy planning, policy, and economics. He or she should have sound 
knowledge of the regional energy market, energy system economics, risk analysis (portfolio-
based planning) in energy planning, and energy pricing policies. The economist should also 
have training and capacity building skills.  
 
11.  Geographic information system specialist (international, 2 person-months). The GIS 
specialist will work with the GMS database and with the GIS specialist of the Core Environment 
Program and Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Initiative in the Greater Mekong Subregion TA 
project2 to collect updated information and produce thematic maps, taking into account the GIS 
database developed by the Word Bank for its studies in the GMS. The specialist will produce 
maps of areas highlighted in the SEAs, and will support the international and national experts in 
using GIS tools and products to analyze the impacts of the GMS Power Transmission Master 
Plan. The specialist will lead the procurement of any equipment needed for completing the 
database  with  GIS  tools.  He  or  she  will  provide  support  to  the  team  leader  in  relevant 
presentations and in training materials. The GIS specialist should have at least 5 years of 
experience in GIS applications. The expert should have skills in training and capacity building. 
 
12.  Hydropower expert (international, 2 person-months). The hydropower expert will carry 
out development reviews of the hydropower subsector for each GMS country. These reviews 
will be based on the 2007 regional TA. The expert will prepare a summary of hydropower in the 
GMS,  focusing  on  development  trends.  He  or  she  will  take  the  lead  in  assessing  the 
environmental, climate change, and social impacts of hydropower in the GMS, and in assessing 
the costs of these impacts for use in the optimization process. Considering the results the SEA 
of hydropower in the Mekong basin produced by the MRC, the expert will analyze the impact of 
increased  or  reduced hydropower  on  other overall  energy  sector. The  expert  will  propose 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Core Environment Program and Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Initiative 
in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila.

Appendix 3       13 
mitigation  and  adaptation  measures  and  will  identify  opportunities  and  challenges  to 
implementing  these  measures.  The  hydropower  expert  should  have  at  least  8  years  of 
experience in hydropower development (large, medium, and small scale), resource simulation, 
modeling and estimation of resource potential, hydropower technologies, generation costs, best 
practices in hydropower, as well as environmental, social, and climate impacts of hydropower 
development. The expert should have skills in training and capacity building.  
 
13.  Social expert (international, 3 person-months). The social expert will prepare a regional 
summary of the key strategic social issues that form the basis of the SEA of the GMS Regional 
Power  Master  Pan.  The  expert  will  lead the analysis  of social  impacts,  both  positive  and 
negative, of energy generation facilities (fossil-fuel-based and hydro-based) and transmission 
systems in each country. The expert will conduct a desk review of social costs, with special 
attention to studies carried out by other development partners, and will recommend values for 
social impacts to be used in the alternative scenario formulation. The expert will take the lead in 
the gender analysis and in promoting gender awareness in energy planning. He or she will 
propose measures to mitigate adverse social impacts, identify opportunities and challenges to 
implementing these measures, and prepare policy recommendations related to mitigating social 
impacts and promoting inclusive gender mainstreaming in the energy sector. The social expert 
should have at least 8 years of experience in social and economic development and/or social 
impact analysis of infrastructure projects, and should have experience in carrying out social, 
economic,  demographic,  and  poverty  analyses.  Knowledge  of  GMS  countries'  cross-sector 
impacts  on,  for  example,  fisheries,  irrigation  and  other  income-generating  industries  is  an 
advantage. 
 
14.  Renewable energy and energy efficiency expert (international, 3 person-months). 
The expert will carry out the analysis of renewable energy developments in GMS countries, 
including analysis of technical and economic resource potential for grid-connected electricity, 
incentive  mechanisms  to  scale  up  renewable  energy  investments,  and  institutional 
arrangements.  The  expert  will  take  the  lead  in  formulating  ambitious  renewable  energy 
scenarios and will estimate the renewable energy potential in the region. He or she will lead the 
formulation of the energy security and efficiency components for the alternative scenarios to the 
GMS Power Transmission Master Plan, analyze the technical and economic electricity savings 
potential  for  major  economic  sectors,  and  highlight  initiatives  and  incentives  to  stimulate 
investments in energy efficiency. The expert will formulate policy recommendations concerning 
the promotion of renewable energy and energy efficiency within the context of the master plan. 
The expert should have at least 8 years of experience in implementing renewable energy 
programs and should have strong knowledge of grid-based renewable energy technologies and 
generation costs, best practices in promoting and scaling up grid integration of renewable 
energy, and estimating renewable resource potential. The expert should have at least 8 years of 
experience  in  implementing  energy  efficiency,  energy  conservation,  and  demand-side 
management programs, and should have strong knowledge of energy efficiency technologies 
and savings costs, best practices in scaling up energy efficiency technologies, and estimating 
energy  efficiency  savings  potential.  The  expert  should  have  skills  in  training  and  capacity 
building. 
 
C.  National Consultants (28 person-months) 
 
15.  Energy planning specialist (national, 6 person-months). The energy planning specialist 
will  assist  the  international  energy  experts  in  the  baseline  analysis  of  the  GMS  Power 
Transmission Master Plan, and participate in the preparation of regional summaries of energy 
trends, energy resources, technologies, energy prices, policy and regulatory frameworks, and

14  Appendix 3      
institutional arrangements. Based on the 2007 regional TA, the specialist will prepare data and 
information required to formulate the alternative scenarios to the master plan and participate in 
formulating the SEAs, taking the lead in analyzing the energy security implications of each 
alternative scenario, particularly relating to the impact of increased or decreased investment in 
renewable energy and energy efficiency in each country. The specialist will identify opportunities 
and challenges to enhancing national and regional energy security. 
 
16.  Environment  specialist  (national,  6  person-months).  The  national  environmental 
specialist will assist the international environment specialist in collecting environmental and 
climate change data for the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan baseline scenario, focusing 
on fossil fuel-based and hydro-based power generation for each GMS country. The specialist 
will participate in monetizing environmental and climate change impacts for the master plan 
baseline and formulation of alternative scenarios. The specialist will pay special attention to 
studies carried out by other development partners in the GMS. For each country, the specialist 
will identify the environmental benefits resulting from the master plan and from the integration of 
GMS country power systems. 
 
17.  Energy economist (national, 4 person-months). The energy economist will assist with 
the formulation of the alternative scenarios of the GMS Power Transmission Master Plan by 
providing inputs on risks associated with fuel price volatility, supply disruptions, and financial 
crises,  as  well  as  the  depletion  of  indigenous  exhaustible  resources  (including  sensitivity 
analysis related to electricity demand and fuel prices). The specialist will suggest ways to 
integrate  these  risks. The  economist  will  analyze  the  energy  security  implications  of  each 
alternative scenario (particularly in mitigating the risks and enhancing the values of exhaustible 
resources), and identify opportunities and challenges to enhancing regional energy security. 
 
18.  Social expert (national, 6 person months). The national social expert will contribute to 
the preparation of a regional summary of the key strategic issues that form the basis of the SEA 
of the GMS Regional Power Master Plan. The expert will contribute to the alternative scenario 
formulation of the master plan, in particular by identifying the social costs of the master plan 
baseline and alternative scenarios in each country. He or she will propose measures to mitigate 
these costs and suggest how to implement these measures.  
 
19.  Renewable energy expert (national, 6 person-months). The renewable energy expert 
will participate in the analysis of renewable energy in GMS countries, focusing on the technical 
and economic resource potential for grid-connected electricity, technology trends and costs, 
policies and programs (including rural energy access programs), incentive mechanisms to scale 
up renewable energy investments, and institutional arrangements. The expert will provide inputs 
related to renewable energy for the master plan baseline and alternative scenario analysis and 
will propose measures and incentive mechanisms to support renewable energy development in 
the alternative scenarios. The expert will identify opportunities and challenges to implementing 
these measures. 
 
20.  All  national  experts  should  have at  least  7 years  of  relevant  experience  and deep 
knowledge of national and GMS-wide developments in their respective fields. Participation in 
ongoing or previous GMS studies and TA projects supported by other development partners is 
an advantage.
